27. ego vero etc„ ‘all that I have learned, witnessed, or read, all that has been put on record by the wisest and most illustrious men, both in our state and in other political com- munities‚ has taught me that the same man is not always to defend the same opinions, but rather those which the position of the state, the bias of the times, and the interests of peace may require.’ For the sentiment cf. the extract in the preceding note. ‘ Cicero was deficient not in honesty but in moral courage ; much too of his inconsistency can be traced to his professional habits as a pleader, which led him to introduce the licence of the Forum into deliberative discussions and (however inexcus- ably) even into his correspondence with his friends. . . Although he was perfectly aware of what was philosophically upright . . he was apt to fancy that the circumstances of his case con-

stituted it an exception to the broad principles of duty.'— J. H. Newman.
